dt: {bc}the equivalent of a specified amount or figure
{bc}the value of something measured by its qualities or by the esteem in which it is held

dt.t: a field in which we have proved our {wi}worth{/wi}

et: Middle English, going back to Old English {it}weorþ, wyrth{/it} (strong neuter noun), going back to Germanic {it}*werþa-{/it} (whence also Old Frisian {it}werth, worth{/it} "value," Old Saxon {it}werth{/it} "payment, price," Old High German {it}werd{/it} "value, price," Old Icelandic {it}verð,{/it} Gothic {it}wairþ{/it} "price"), noun derivative from {it}*werþa-,{/it} adjective, "of value" {ma}{mat|worth:3|}{/ma}
shortdef: the equivalent of a specified amount or figure
the value of something measured by its qualities or by the esteem in which it is held

dt: {bc}of substantial or significant value or merit

shortdef: having assets or income equal to

dt: {bc}to the fullest extent of one's value or ability

et: Middle English, "having monetary value, valuable, having status, deserving, highborn, efficacious, strong," going back to Old English {it}weorþ, wyrþ, worþ{/it} "having monetary value, valuable," going back to Germanic {it}*werþa-{/it} (whence also Old Frisian {it}werth{/it} "of value," Old Saxon {it}werth{/it} "of value, worthy, dear," Old High German {it}werd, wert{/it} "of value, valuable," Old Icelandic {it}verðr{/it} "of value, worthy," Gothic {it}wairþs{/it} "deserving"), of uncertain origin

The Middle English adjective continues in part Old English {it}wierðe, wyrðe{/it} "worthy, deserving," a ja-stem adjective from the same base. Welsh {it}gwerth{/it} "worth, value, price" (whence {it}gwerthu{/it} "to sell"), along with Middle Breton {it}guerz,{/it} is perhaps an early loan from Old English.

dt: usually used in the phrase {it}woe worth{/it}

et: Middle English {it}worthen{/it} "to exist, be, come into existence, become, change, happen," going back to Old English {it}weorþan, wurþan{/it} (class III strong verb) "to become, come to be, happen," going back to Germanic {it}*werþan-{/it} (whence also Old Frisian {it}wertha{/it} "to become, happen, arise," Old Saxon {it}werthan,{/it} Old High German {it}werdan,{/it} Old Icelandic {it}verða,{/it} Gothic {it}wairþan{/it} "to become"), going back to an Indo-European verbal base {it}*u̯ert-{/it} "turn," whence also Latin {it}vertō, vertere{/it} "to cause to revolve, turn, spin," {it}vertor{/it} "(I) change direction, turn," Lithuanian {it}verčiù, ver͂sti{/it} "to cause to turn," Sanskrit {it}vártate{/it} "(it) turns, rolls, revolves"; with zero-grade ablaut Old Church Slavic {it}vrǔštǫ, vrǔteti sę{/it} "to turn oneself"; with a causative stem {it}*u̯ort-{/it} Old Church Slavic {it}vraštǫ, vratiti{/it} "to make turn," Sanskrit {it}vartáyati{/it} "(s/he) makes turn"; from an n-present Old Church Slavic {it}obvrǔnǫti sę{/it} "to turn around," Tocharian B {it}wärnāmane{/it} "turning"

In Germanic the Indo-European base {it}*u̯ert-{/it} "turn" developed the figurative sense "become, happen" (compare, in English, "the milk turned sour"), which has largely displaced the literal senses (but compare the suffix {it}*-wearda-{/it} {et_link|-ward:1|-ward:1}).
shortdef: become —usually used in the phrase woe worth

dt: inlet (lagoon) of the Atlantic in southeastern Florida

shortdef: inlet (lagoon) of the Atlantic in southeastern Florida

dt.t: I don't know if this new medicine will help, but I think it's {it}worth a go{/it}.

dt: {bc}be good, valuable, or important enough for (something/someone)

dt.t: If you ask me, his opinions aren't {it}worth a tinker's damn{/it}.

shortdef: be good, valuable, or important enough for (something/someone) —used in negative statements

dt: {bc}worth the entire amount that was paid for something

dt.t: Our vacation was expensive, but it was {it}worth every penny{/it}.

shortdef: worth the entire amount that was paid for something

dt.t: Good teachers are {it}worth their weight in gold{/it}.
An experience like that is {it}worth its weight in gold{/it}.
It would be {it}worth your while{/it} to study the material again before the test.
If you help me I'll {phrase}make it worth your while{/phrase}.
